newsitem.title: USA: CBOT soyoil hits contract lows on crop prospects.
newsitem.headline: CBOT soyoil hits contract lows on crop prospects.

text.p: Prospects for a big 1997/98 (Aug/Sept) soybean crop helped push CBOT soyoil futures to fresh contract lows early Monday, traders said.
Soymeal futures were also lower, mostly in line with soybeans.
The soy complex was under pressure from weather considered ideal for the development of the new soybean crop, traders said.
Additionally, cash sources reported high temperatures in the U.S. have caused a drop in demand for soymeal because animals eat less when it is hot outside.
The fresh lows in soyoil futures could spark some export interest in U.S. soyoil. Prices in the U.S. are moving closer to those in South America, CBOT traders said.

The soy product markets could also find support from a slowdown in crush rates. On Friday, ADM confirmed that it was slowing its crush operations because of falling margins and tight soybean supplies.
At 1002 CDT, July soyoil was 0.09 cent a lb lower at 22.76 cents and other months were 0.10 to 0.16 lower. July soymeal was down $3.40 at $267.70 per ton and other months were $0.30 to $2.10 lower.
